G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a719 & 21.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§19 & 21 and G.L. c. 231, §2, as the claims arise from a residential tenancy located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a72.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§19 & 21 and G.L. c. 231, §2, as the claims arise from a residential tenancy located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14, every residential tenancy in Massachusetts contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guaranteeing the tenant the right to occupy leased premises free from material interference by the landlord.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case does not involve mold or ventilation defects, but it directly holds that a landlord’s failure to correct conditions within the landlord’s control that ‘very substantially’ deprive tenants of quiet enjoyment constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct (including what is ‘failed to do’ or ‘permitted to be done’) can violate quiet enjoyment when it results in premises that are not reasonably habitable. By analogy, permitting persistent mold and refusing to repair ventilation defects that substantially interfere with habitability fits squarely within this principle, so the case provides supportive authority at a general doctrinal level.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. … Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight premises, resulting in repeated sewage/water flooding, is both a breach of the warranty of habitability and an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Although the facts involve flooding rather than mold or ventilation defects specifically, the court’s reasoning is grounded in the landlord’s duty to maintain habitable, sanitary premises and recognizes that permitting recurring unsanitary conditions that substantially impair use of the unit constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports, by close analogy, the proposition that persistent, unrepaired habitability defects (like mold/ventilation problems) can amount to substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey… Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway… The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.raw_text: McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429 Mass. 300 (1999)
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.support_reasoning: The case rejects expanding warranty of habitability/quiet enjoyment liability to conditions like exterior snow and ice, and emphasizes that only significant defects in the property itself that affect habitability fall under the implied warranty. While it cites examples of serious conditions (including Simon v. Solomon), this opinion itself does not involve or hold that persistent mold or ventilation defects constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. It therefore does not affirm the specific proposition about mold and ventilation problems; at most it distinguishes lesser conditions from those that would qualify.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.relevant_excerpt: “The implied warranty of habitability ‘is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises’ (emphasis in original). … Not every breach of the State sanitary code supports a claim under the implied warranty of habitability. Rather, the implied warranty of habitability applies to significant defects in the property itself. Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201-202 (1979) (‘A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable’). … The natural accumulation of snow and ice is not such a defect.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case concerns a failure to provide security against criminal drug activity in common areas, not failure to repair physical defects like mold or ventilation. The court expressly limits breach of the implied warranty of habitability to defects in physical facilities and refuses to treat nonphysical conditions (like criminal activity) as habitability breaches, and its quiet-enjoyment analysis is tied to the landlord’s inaction regarding third-party criminal conduct, not maintenance problems. Thus, it does not provide authority that persistent mold and unremedied ventilation defects constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment… .”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The case does discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it holds that there was no breach on the facts presented and that there was no evidence of interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The opinion does not involve mold, persistent failure to repair ventilation defects, or any finding that such conditions constitute a substantial interference; instead, it affirms judgment for the landlord because the landlord promptly repaired conditions and did not substantially interfere with the tenancy. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that the described failures constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. … We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. … The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landlord’s failure to provide heat and holds that such failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of the landlord’s financial inability. It does not address mold, ventilation defects, or a more general duty to maintain premises in a safe and habitable condition. Therefore, using this case as authority for interference with quiet enjoyment based specifically on mold and ventilation problems extends the holding beyond its actual facts and reasoning.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses implied warranty of habitability and statutory housing standards, but it does not frame the landlord’s violations as a ‘substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.’ The focus is on rent liability and the tenant’s ability to assert code violations as a defense or basis for reducing rent, not on a quiet enjoyment theory or on conditions like mold and defective ventilation specifically. Thus, it is not good authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated, even though it deals broadly with uninhabitable conditions.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The answer of each tenant alleges that the landlord in these cases is ‘…requiring it to keep its premises in a safe and sanitary and habitable condition; and that the failure of [the] plaintiff herein ... to lease and maintain the premises in such condition is a breach of its implied warrantee [sic] of habitability to defendant and that defendant’s obligation to pay rent is dependent upon plaintiff’s performance of its Warrantee [sic] of Inhabitability….’ … [T]he landlord impliedly warranted the fitness of their apartments for habitation….”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions State Sanitary Code violations and a breach of the warranty of habitability but does not discuss mold, ventilation defects, or ‘quiet enjoyment’ as a legal theory. The court affirms only a rent abatement for habitability issues and notes many of the code violations had minimal impact on use and enjoyment, without framing them as a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not establish or analyze the specific quiet-enjoyment principle asserted in the proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code…have existed in the tenant’s apartment… The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs… Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability… The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a statutory violation (the lead paint law) automatically constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court holds that it does not and that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. While the case acknowledges that failure to repair known defects can violate § 14, it does not specifically address conditions like mold or ventilation defects, nor does it hold that such failures necessarily constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment as framed in the proposition.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a safe and habitable condition, including permitting persistent mold growth and refusing to repair the ventilation defects, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
